Title: A Hitchhiker‚Äôs Ride to Space
Content:
This month, we are set to launch the latest weather satellite from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA). The Joint Polar Satellite System-1, or JPSS-1, satellite will provide essential data for timely and accurate weather forecasts and for tracking environmental events such as forest fires and droughts.

"
Source_URL: https://nasa.tumblr.com/post/167317844394/a-hitchhikers-ride-to-space

Title: September 2017 Was¬†üî• on the Sun
Content: The Sun started September 2017 with flair
Source_URL: emitting 31 sizable solar flares and releasing several powerful coronal mass ejections
column7:
between Sept. 6-10.

Solar flares are powerful bursts of radiation. Harmful radiation from a flare cannot pass through Earth‚Äôs atmosphere to physically affect humans on the ground
column8:
however ‚Äî when intense enough ‚Äî they can disturb the atmosphere in the layer where GPS and communications signals travel.¬†

CMEs are massive clouds of solar material and magnetic fields that erupt from the Sun at incredible speeds. Depending on the direction they‚Äôre traveling in
column9:
CMEs can spark powerful geomagnetic storms in Earth‚Äôs magnetic field.

As always
column10: we and our partners had many missions observing the Sun from both Earth and space
column11: enabling scientists to study these events from multiple perspectives. With this integrated picture of solar activity
column12:
scientists can better track the evolution of solar eruptions and work toward improving our understanding of space weather.

The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA)‚Äôs Geostationary Operational Environmental Satellite-16
column14: watches the Sun‚Äôs upper atmosphere ‚Äî called the corona ‚Äî at six different wavelengths
column15: allowing it to observe a wide range of solar phenomena. GOES-16 caught this footage of an X9.3 flare on Sept. 6
column16:
2017.¬†

This was the most intense flare recorded during the current 11-year solar cycle. X-class denotes the most intense flares
column17: while the number provides more information about its strength. An X2 is twice as intense as an X1
column18: an X3 is three times as intense
column19:
and so on. GOES also detected solar energetic particles associated with this activity.

Our Solar Dynamics Observatory captured these images of X2.2 and X9.3 flares on Sept. 6
column21:
in a wavelength of extreme ultraviolet light that shows solar material heated to over one million degrees Fahrenheit.

JAXA/NASA‚Äôs Hinode caught this video of an X8.2 flare on Sept. 10
column23: the second largest flare of this solar cycle
column24:
with its X-ray Telescope. The instrument captures X-ray images of the corona to help scientists link changes in the Sun‚Äôs magnetic field to explosive solar events like this flare.

Key instruments aboard our Solar and Terrestrial Relations Observatory
column26: include a pair of coronagraphs ‚Äî instruments that use a metal disk called an occulting disk to study the corona. The occulting disk blocks the Sun‚Äôs bright light
column27:
making it possible to discern the detailed features of the Sun‚Äôs outer atmosphere and track coronal mass ejections as they erupt from the Sun.

On Sept. 9
column29: STEREO watched a CME erupt from the Sun. The next day
column30: STEREO observed an even bigger CME. The Sept. 10 CME traveled away from the Sun at calculated speeds as high as 7 million mph
column31: and was one of the fastest CMEs ever recorded. The CME was not Earth-directed: It side-swiped Earth‚Äôs magnetic field
column32:
and therefore did not cause significant geomagnetic activity. Mercury is in view as the bright white dot moving leftwards in the frame.

Like STEREO
column35: uses a coronagraph to track solar storms. SOHO also observed the CMEs that occurred during Sept. 9-10
column36: 2017; multiple views provide more information for space weather models. As the CME expands beyond SOHO‚Äôs field of view
column37:
a flurry of what looks like snow floods the frame. These are high-energy particles flung out ahead of the CME at near-light speeds that struck SOHO‚Äôs imager.

Our Interface Region Imaging Spectrometer
column41: showing jets of solar material swimming down toward the Sun‚Äôs surface. These structures are sometimes observed in the corona during solar flares
column42:
and this particular set was associated with the X8.2 flare of the same day.¬†¬†

Our Solar Radiation and Climate Experiment
column44: collected the above data on total solar irradiance
column45: the total amount of the Sun‚Äôs radiant energy
column46: throughout Sept. 2017. While the Sun produced high levels of extreme ultraviolet light
column47:
SORCE actually detected a dip in total irradiance during the month‚Äôs intense solar activity.¬†

A possible explanation for this observation is that over the active regions ‚Äî where solar flares originate ‚Äî the darkening effect of sunspots is greater than the brightening effect of the flare‚Äôs extreme ultraviolet emissions. As a result
column48:
the total solar irradiance suddenly dropped during the flare events.¬†

Scientists gather long-term solar irradiance data in order to understand not only our dynamic star
column49: but also its relationship to Earth‚Äôs environment and climate. We are ready to launch the Total Spectral solar Irradiance Sensor-1
column51:
this December to continue making total solar irradiance measurements.

The intense solar activity also sparked global aurora on Mars more than 25 times brighter than any previously seen by NASA‚Äôs Mars Atmosphere and Volatile Evolution
column53: mission. MAVEN studies the Martian atmosphere‚Äôs interaction with the solar wind
column54:
the constant flow of charged particles from the Sun. These images from MAVEN‚Äôs Imaging Ultraviolet Spectrograph show the appearance of bright aurora on Mars during the September solar storm. The purple-white colors show the intensity of ultraviolet light on Mars‚Äô night side before (left) and during (right) the event.

For all the latest on solar and space weather research
column55:
follow us on Twitter @NASASun or Facebook.

GOES images are courtesy of NOAA. Hinode images are courtesy of JAXA and NASA. SOHO images are courtesy of ESA and NASA.¬†

Make sure to follow us on Tumblr for your regular dose of space: http://nasa.tumblr.com.

"

Title: Solar System: 10 Things to Know This Week
Content:
Every day, our spacecraft and people are exploring the solar system. Both the public and the private sectors are contributing to the quest. For example, here are ten things happening just this week:

1. We deliver.¬†

The commercial space company Orbital ATK is targeting Saturday
Source_URL: Nov. 11 for the launch of its Cygnus spacecraft on an Antares rocket from Wallops Flight Facility in Wallops Island
column6: Virginia. Cygnus is launching on a resupply mission to the International Space Station
column7:
carrying cargo and scientific experiments to the six people currently living on the microgravity laboratory.¬†

2. See for yourself.¬†

Social media users are invited to register to attend another launch in person
column8: this one of a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket carrying the Dragon spacecraft from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station in Florida. This launch
column9: currently targeted for no earlier than December
column10:
will be the next commercial cargo resupply mission to the International Space Station. The deadline to apply is Nov. 7. Apply HERE.

3. Who doesn’t like to gaze at the Moon?

Our Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter (LRO) sure does‚Äîand from very close range. This robotic spacecraft has been orbiting Earth’s companion since 2009
column11: returning views of the lunar surface that are so sharp they show the footpaths made by Apollo astronauts. Learn more about LRO and the entire history of lunar exploration at NASA’s newly-updated
column12:
expanded Moon site:¬†moon.nasa.gov

4. Meanwhile at Mars…

Another sharp-eyed robotic spacecraft has just delivered a fresh batch of equally detailed images. Our Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter (MRO) surveys the Red Planet’s surface daily
column13: and you can see the very latest pictures of those exotic landscapes HERE. We currently operate five‚Äîcount ‘em
column15:
with another (the InSight lander) launching next year. Track them all at: mars.nasa.gov.

5. Always curious.¬†

One of those missions is the Curiosity rover. It’s currently climbing a rocky highland dubbed Vera Rubin Ridge
column16: turning its full array of instruments on the intriguing geology there. Using those instruments
column17:
Curiosity can see things you and I can’t.

6. A new Dawn.¬†

Our voyage to the asteroid belt has a new lease on life. The Dawn spacecraft recently received a mission extension to continue exploring the dwarf planet Ceres. This is exciting because minerals containing water are widespread on Ceres
column18:
suggesting it may have had a global ocean in the past. What became of that ocean? Could Ceres still have liquid today? Ongoing studies from Dawn¬†could shed light on these questions.

7. There are eyes everywhere.¬†

When our Mars Pathfinder touched down in 1997
column19: it had five cameras: two on a mast that popped up from the lander
column22: photo sensors that were improved by the space program have shrunk in size
column23: increased in quality and are now carried in every cellphone. That same evolution has returned to space. Our Mars 2020 mission will have more “eyes” than any rover before it: a grand total of 23
column27:
and assist science instruments.

8. Voyage to a hidden ocean.

One of the most intriguing destinations in the solar system is Jupiter’s moon Europa
column28: which hides a global ocean of liquid water beneath its icy shell. Our Europa Clipper mission sets sail in the 2020s to take a closer look than we’ve ever had before. You can explore Europa
column29:
too:¬†europa.nasa.gov

9. Flight of the mockingbird.¬†

On Nov. 10
column31: named for the legendary author of To Kill a Mockingbird
column32: makes its closest approach to Earth during the asteroid’s orbit around the Sun. Details HERE. Learn more about asteroids HERE.¬†Meanwhile
column33: our OSIRIS-REx mission is now cruising toward another tiny
column34:
rocky world called Bennu.

10. What else is up this month?¬†

For sky watchers
column35: there will be a pre-dawn pairing of Jupiter and Venus
column36: the Moon will shine near some star clusters
column37:
and there will be meteor activity all month long. Catch our monthly video blog for stargazers HERE.

Make sure to follow us on Tumblr for your regular dose of space: http://nasa.tumblr.com.

"

Title: What‚Äôs Up November 2017
Content:
What‚Äôs Up For November?

Dawn pairing of Jupiter and Venus, Moon shines near star clusters, meteor activity all month long!

This month binoculars will come in handy–to view the moon
Source_URL: star clusters
column6:
and a close pairing of Venus and Jupiter.

You can‚Äôt miss bright Venus in the predawn sky. This month Venus pairs up
with Jupiter on the morning of November 13th.

The Leonids peak on a moonless November 17th. Expect no more than 10 meteors an hour around 3:00 a.m.
column7:
the height of the shower.

The Northern and Southern sub-branches of the Taurid meteor shower offer sparse counts of about 5 meteors per hour
column9:
bright meteors are common.

The nearby November Orionids peak on the 28th. In contrast to the Taurids
column10:
the Orionids are swift. But don‚Äôt expect more than 3 meteors per hour.

The moon glides by three beautiful star clusters in the morning sky this month
column11:
and a pair of binoculars will allow you to see the individual stars in the clusters. Aim your binoculars at the Pleiades and the moon on the 5th.

Then aim at the Messier or M-35 cluster¬†and the moon on the 7th and the Beehive cluster and the moon on the 10th.

Meanwhile
column13:
catch Saturn as it dips closer to the western horizon and pairs up with Mercury on the 24th through the 28th.

Also
column14: Comet C/2017 O1 should still be a binocular-friendly magnitude 7 or 8 greenish object in November. Use Polaris
column15:
the North Star as a guide. Look in the East to Northeast sky in the late evening. ¬†

Watch the full What‚Äôs Up for November Video:¬†

Make sure to follow us on Tumblr for your regular dose of space: http://nasa.tumblr.com. ¬†

"

Title: Solar System: 10 Things to Know This Week...Halloween Edition!
Content:
This week, we’re getting into the Halloween spirit with 10 spooktacular things to let your imagination run wild.¬†

It’s not Halloween without our favorite scary characters
Source_URL: but what if they could stop bothering us Earthlings and go far
column6: far away? We begin with where Dracula
column8:
and other creepy creatures might choose to live if the galaxy were theirs to claim…

1. The dark (k)night.

The prince of darkness himself
column10: can finally seek sweet respite from the Sun. We think he’d love to live on a rocky planet named YZ Ceti d that orbits so close to its red star that it’s tidally locked keeping one side of the planet in perpetual nighttime and the other side in perpetual daytime
column11:
with a brilliant red sky (though we can guess which side Dracula will prefer).¬†

2. Where art thou
column12:
werewolves?¬†

Home sweet home for our furry Full Moon friends might just be on Trappist-1
column13:
a planetary system with seven planets‚Äîand where standing on one planet would mean the other planets look like six moons (some as big as our Moon in the sky).¬†

3. Left in the dust.¬†

We couldn’t think of anyone better to live on Proxima b than The Mummy. Hopefully this ancient monster can finally rest in peace on an exoplanet that scientists theorize is a desert planet once home to ancient oceans.¬†

4. Cloudy with a chance of Frankenstein.

One scientific experiment we’d like to conduct: whether Frankenstein would rather live on HAT-P-11b or Kepler-3b
column14:
theorized to have fierce thunderstorms and lightning.¬†

5. The walking dead.¬†

We’re pretty confident that if zombies were to pick a planet
column15: they’d want one that shares their love of death and destruction. We think they’d feel right at home on one of the pulsar planets
column16:
which are scorched by radiation because they orbit a dead star.¬†

6. Rest your weary bones.¬†

Skeletons need look no further: Osiris
column17: an exoplanet that’s so close to a star that it’s “losing its flesh” as the star destroys it
column18:
seems like a perfect match.¬†

7. Enough of the scary stuff.¬†

For kids out there
column19: turn pumpkin decorating into an out-of-this-world activity with space-themed stencils
column20:
from Saturn to the Sun.¬†

8. Spooky sounds.¬†

Cassini’s radio emissions from Saturn could give creaky doors and howling winds a run for their money. Listen to the eerie audio recordings here and find more HERE.

9. Pumpkin-carve like a NASA engineer.¬†

NASA engineers design and build robots that can fly millions of miles to study other planets for a living‚Äîso on Halloween
column21:
they can’t help but bring that creative thinking to the grand old tradition of pumpkin carving. Take a cue from their creations with these insider tips.

10. Detective for a day.¬†

From blades of ice on Pluto to a fuzzy
column23:
become a solar system sleuth and see if you can solve the stellar mysteries in this slideshow (then compare with how scientists cracked the case).¬†

Make sure to follow us on Tumblr for your regular dose of space: http://nasa.tumblr.com.

"

Title: Spooky Sounds from Across the Solar System
Content:
Soaring to the depths of our universe, gallant spacecraft roam the cosmos, snapping images of celestial wonders. Some spacecraft have instruments capable of capturing radio emissions. When scientists convert these to sound waves, the results are eerie to hear.

In time for Halloween, we’ve put together a compilation of elusive “sounds” of howling planets and whistling helium that is sure to make your skin crawl.

Listen to a few here and visit our Soundcloud for more spooky sounds.¬†

Cassini Ring Crossing

This eerie audio represents data collected by our Cassini spacecraft
Source_URL: as it crossed through the gap between Saturn and its rings on April 26
column7: during the first dive of the mission’s Grand Finale. The instrument is able to record ring particles striking the spacecraft in its data. In the data from this dive
column8:
there is virtually no detectable peak in pops and cracks that represent ring particles striking the spacecraft. The lack of discernible pops and cracks indicates the region is largely free of small particles.¬†

Voyager Tsunami Waves in Interstellar Space¬†

Listen to this howling audio from our¬†Voyager 1 spacecraft. Voyager 1 has experienced three “tsunami waves” in interstellar space. This kind of wave occurs as a result of a coronal mass ejection erupting from the Sun. The most recent tsunami wave that Voyager experienced began in February 2014
column9:
and may still be going. Listen to how these waves cause surrounding ionized matter to ring like a bell.

Voyager Sounds of Interstellar Space

Our Voyager 1 spacecraft captured these high-pitched
column10:
spooky sounds of interstellar space from October to November 2012 and April to May 2013.

The soundtrack reproduces the amplitude and frequency of the plasma waves as “heard” by Voyager 1. The waves detected by the instrument antennas can be simply amplified and played through a speaker. These frequencies are within the range heard by human ears.

When scientists extrapolated this line even further back in time (not shown)
column11:
they deduced that Voyager 1 first encountered interstellar plasma in August 2012.

Plasma Sounds at Jupiter

Ominous sounds of plasma! Our Juno spacecraft has observed plasma wave signals from Jupiter‚Äôs ionosphere. The results in this video show an increasing plasma density as Juno descended into Jupiter‚Äôs ionosphere during its close pass by Jupiter on February 2
column12:
2017. ¬†

Roar of Jupiter

Juno’s Waves instrument recorded this supernatural sounding¬†encounter with the bow shock over the course of about two hours on June 24
column13: 2016. “Bow shock” is where the supersonic solar wind is heated and slowed by Jupiter’s magnetosphere. It is analogous to a sonic boom on Earth. The next day
column16:
the Waves instrument witnessed the crossing of the magnetopause. “Trapped continuum radiation” refers to waves trapped in a low-density cavity in Jupiter’s magnetosphere.

Visit the NASA Soundcloud for more spooky space sounds:¬†https://soundcloud.com/nasa/sets/spookyspacesounds

Make sure to follow us on Tumblr for your regular dose of space: http://nasa.tumblr.com.

"

Title: 5 things that may surprise you about the Moon
Content:
…In honor of International Observe the Moon Night

October 28th is International Observe the Moon Night
Source_URL: a worldwide
column6: public celebration of lunar science and exploration held annually since 2010 thanks to our Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter (LRO) mission team and partners. One day each year
column7: everyone on Earth is invited to observe and learn about the Moon together
column8:
and to celebrate the cultural and personal connections we all have with our planet‚Äôs nearest neighbor.

Here are 5 things that might surprise you about the Moon.

1. There has been a spacecraft there for 100 lunar days

In October 2017
column9: LRO celebrates one hundred days of collecting scientific data at the Moon. One hundred Moon days. From our perspective on Earth
column10: one lunar day is one full phase cycle
column11: or about 29.5 Earth days. That’s 100 opportunities to observe changes from night to day
column12: photograph the surface at different Sun angles
column14: study the way certain chemicals react to the daily light and temperature cycle
column15:
and increase our understanding of the Moon as a dynamic place.

2. You can still see the paths left by Apollo astronauts‚Äô boot prints and rovers

Much of the lunar surface is covered in very fine dust. When Apollo astronauts landed on the Moon
column16: the descent stage engine disturbed the dust and produced a distinct bright halo around the lunar module. As astronauts moved around
column17: their tracks exposed the darker soil underneath
column18: creating distinct trails that we know
column20: are still visible today. The Moon has no atmosphere
column21:
so there is no wind to wipe away these tracks.

3. The Moon has tattoos!

Observations from LRO show mysterious patterns of light and dark that are unique to the Moon. These lunar swirls look painted on
column22: like the Moon got ‚Äòinked.‚Äô Lunar swirls
column23: like these imaged at Reiner Gamma by LRO
column24:
are found at more than 100 locations across the lunar surface. Lunar swirls can be tens of miles across and appear in groups or as isolated features.¬†

Researchers think these patterns form in places where there‚Äôs still a remnant of the Moon‚Äôs magnetic field. There are still many competing theories about how swirls form
column25: but the primary idea is that the local magnetic field deflects the energetic particles in the solar wind
column26:
so there‚Äôs not as much weathering of the surface. The magnetically shielded areas would then look brighter than everything around them.

4. There were once active volcanoes
column27:
that shaped what we see now

Early astronomers named the large dark spots that we see on the near side of the Moon ‚Äúmaria
column29: ‚Äù because that‚Äôs what they thought they were. We now know that the dark spots are cooled lava
column31: formed from ancient volcanic eruptions. The Moon‚Äôs volcanoes are no longer active
column32: but their past shapes the Moon that we see today.¬†The Moon doesn‚Äôt have large volcanoes like ones in Hawaii
column33:
but it does have smaller cones and domes.¬†

Other small features derived from volcanic activity include rivers of dried lava flows
column34: like the ones visible in this image of Vallis Schroteri taken by LRO
column35: and dark areas formed from eruptive volcanoes that spewed fire. For many years
column36: scientists thought the Moon‚Äôs volcanic activity died out long ago
column37: but there‚Äôs some evidence for relatively ‚Äúyoung‚Äù volcanism
column38:
suggesting that the activity gradually slowed down instead of stopping abruptly.

5. Anyone
column39:
anywhere can participate in International Observe the Moon Night. ¬†

How to celebrate International Observe the Moon Night

  1. Attend an event ‚Äì ¬†See where events are happening near you by visiting http://observethemoonnight.org
  2. Host an event ‚Äì Call up your neighbors and friends and head outdoors ‚Äì no special equipment is needed. Let us know how you celebrated by registering your event!
  3. Don‚Äôt let cloudy weather get you down! Observe the Moon in a variety of ways from the comfort of indoors ‚Äì View stunning lunar vistas through images and videos
column40:
or explore the Moon on your own with QuickMap or Moon Trek
  • Join the worldwide conversation with #ObserveTheMoon on Twitter
column41:
Instagram and Facebook
  • For regular Moon-related facts
column43:
follow @NASAMoon on Twitter

Make sure to follow us on Tumblr for your regular dose of space: http://nasa.tumblr.com.

"

Title: Taking the Vital Signs of Mars
Content:
Does Mars have quakes?¬†What is the temperature of the Red Planet?¬†How did Mars even form?¬†What can it tell us about how other rocky planets formed?

The¬†Mars InSight lander is scheduled to launch in May 2018 to search for the answers to those questions.

InSight (Interior Exploration using Seismic Investigations
Source_URL: Geodesy and Heat Transport) will conduct the first thorough ‚Äúcheck-up‚Äù of Mars in more than 4.5 billion years
column7:
or seismic activity; its temperature; and its ‚Äúreflexes‚Äù (the way the planet wobbles when it is pulled by the Sun and its moons).

How and Why?

By using sophisticated instruments ‚Äì tools that can measure the vital signs of a planet ‚Äì InSight will delve deep beneath the surface of Mars
column8:
detecting the clues left by the earliest stages of planetary formation. ¬†

Previous Mars missions have explored the surface history of the Red Planet. Mars has been less geologically active than Earth
column9: so it retains a more complete record of its history in its core
column10: mantle and crust. InSight will study the sizes
column11: densities and overall structure of the Red Planet‚Äôs core
column12:
mantle and crust.¬†

The lander will also measure the rate at which heat escapes from the planet‚Äôs interior
column13: and provide glimpses into the evolutionary processes of all the rocky planets in our solar system
column15:
and even those circling other stars!

Send Your Name to Mars!

You can send your name to Mars onboard the InSight lander! The deadline to get your Martian boarding pass is Nov. 1. To submit your name
column16:
visit: mars.nasa.gov/syn/insight

Learn more about Mars InSight HERE.

Make sure to follow us on Tumblr for your regular dose of space: http://nasa.tumblr.com.

"

Title: Solar System: Things To Know This Week
Content:
Weather permitting, you can observe the Moon most nights, unless it’s a new moon, when the lighted side of the Moon faces away from Earth. The Moon is by far the brightest object in the night sky and there’s plenty to see. But this week is special…

…October 28 is International Observe the Moon Night (also known as InOMN).

Here’s all you need to know to join in and celebrate:

1. One Planet. One Moon. One Night.

Everyone on Earth is invited to join the celebration by hosting or attending an InOMN event and uniting on one day each year to look at and learn about the Moon together.

2. What’s Up?

October’s night skies are full of sights
Source_URL:
from the first quarter Moon on InOMN to Saturn making a cameo appearance above the Moon October 23 and 24. Watch our What’s Up video for details.

3. Be Social

Hundreds of events are planned around the globe. Click the top link on this page for a handy map. You can also register your own event.

4. Don’t Just Stand There

Here are some activities for enhanced Moon watching.

5. Impress Your Friends with Moon Knowledge

Download InOMN flyers and handouts
column6:
Moon maps and even some pre-made presentations. There’s even a certificate to mark your participation.

6. Guide to the Face of the Moon

Almost dead center on the Earth-facing side of the Moon is the Surveyor 6 robotic spacecraft impact side. Apollo 12 and 14 are a bit to the left. And Apollo 11 - the first steps on the moon - are to the right. This retro graphic tells the whole story.

7. Moon Shots

NASA photographers have done some exceptional work capturing views of the Moon from Earth. Here are a few galleries:

  • You can’t have a solar eclipse without the Moon.
  • The 2016 “Supermoon” was pretty spectacular.
  • The Moon gets eclipsed
column7:
too.
  • That IS a Moon - AND the International Space Station.
  • The Moon is always a great photo subject.
  • Some spooky shots of the 2014 “Supermoon.”
  • And 2013.
  • Tips from a NASA pro for photographing the Moon.

    • 8. Walking on the Moon

    Twelve human beings walked on the face of the Moon. Here are some of the best shots from the Apollo program.

    9. Moon Watch

    Our Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter is up there right now
column8:
mapping the moon and capturing some spectacular high-resolution shots.

10. Keep Exploring

Make our¬†Moon portal your base for further lunar exploration.

Check out the full version of ‚ÄòTen Things to Know This Week‚Äô HERE.

Make sure to follow us on Tumblr for your regular dose of space: http://nasa.tumblr.com.

"

Title: Spacewalk Recap Told in GIFs
Content: Friday, Oct. 20, NASA astronauts Randy Bresnik and Joe Acaba ventured outside the International Space Station for a 6 hour and 49 minute spacewalk. Just like you make improvements to your home on Earth
Source_URL:
astronauts living in space periodically go outside the space station to make updates on their orbiting home.

During this spacewalk
column6:
they did a lot! Here‚Äôs a recap of their day told in GIFs‚Ä¶

All spacewalks begin inside the space station. Astronauts Paolo Nespoli and Mark Vande Hei helped each spacewalker put on their suit
column7:
known as an Extravehicular Mobility Unit (EMU).

They then enter an airlock and regulate the pressure so that they can enter the vacuum of space safely. If they did not regulate the pressure safely
column8:
the astronauts could experience something referred to as ‚Äúthe bends‚Äù ‚Äì similar to scuba divers.

Once the two astronauts exited the airlock and were outside the space station
column9:
they went to their respective work stations.

Bresnik replaced a failed fuse on the end of the Dextre robotic arm extension
column10:
which helps capture visiting vehicles.

During that time
column11:
Acaba set up a portable foot restraint to help him get in the right position to install a new camera.

While he was getting set up
column12: he realized that there was unexpected wearing on one of his safety tethers. Astronauts have multiple safety mechanisms for spacewalking
column13: including a ‚Äújet pack‚Äù on their spacesuit. That way
column14: in the unlikely instance they become untethered from the station
column15:
the are able to propel back to safety.

Bresnik was a great teammate and brought Acaba a spare safety tether to use.

Once Acaba secured himself in the foot restraint that was attached to the end of the station‚Äôs robotic arm
column16:
he was maneuvered into place to install a new HD camera. Who was moving the arm? Astronauts inside the station were carefully moving it into place!

And
column17: ta da! Below you can see one of the first views from the new enhanced HD camera‚Ä¶(sorry
column18:
not a GIF).

After Acaba installed the new HD camera
column19:
he repaired the camera system on the end of the robotic arm‚Äôs hand. This ensures that the hand can see the vehicles that it‚Äôs capturing.

Bresnik
column20:
completed all of his planned tasks and moved on to a few ‚Äúget ahead‚Äù tasks. He first started removing extra thermal insulation straps around some spare pumps. This will allow easier access to these spare parts if and when they‚Äôre needed in the future.

He then worked to install a new handle on the outside of space station. That‚Äôs a space drill in the above GIF.¬†

After Acaba finished working on the robotic arm‚Äôs camera
column21: he began greasing bearings on the new latching end effector (the arm‚Äôs ‚Äúhand‚Äù)
column22:
which was just installed on Oct. 5.

The duo completed all planned spacewalk tasks
column23:
cleaned up their work stations and headed back to the station‚Äôs airlock.¬†

Once safely inside the airlock and pressure was restored to the proper levels
column24:
the duo was greeted by the crew onboard.¬†

They took images of their spacesuits to document any possible tears
column26:
and took them off.¬†

Coverage ended at 2:36 p.m. EDT after 6 hours and 49 minutes. We hope the pair was able to grab some dinner and take a break!

You can watch the entire spacewalk HERE
column27:
or follow @Space_Station on Twitter and Instagram for regular updates on the orbiting laboratory.¬†

Make sure to follow us on Tumblr for your regular dose of space: http://nasa.tumblr.com.

"

Title: Why Webb Needs to Chill
Content:
Our massive James Webb Space Telescope is currently being tested to make sure it can work perfectly at incredibly cold temperatures when it‚Äôs in deep space.¬†

How cold is it getting and why? Here‚Äôs the whole scoop…

Webb is a giant infrared space telescope¬†that we are currently building. It was designed to see things that other telescopes
Source_URL: even the amazing Hubble Space Telescope
column6:
can‚Äôt see. ¬†

Webb‚Äôs giant 6.5-meter diameter primary mirror is part of what gives it superior vision
column7:
and it‚Äôs coated in gold to optimize it for seeing infrared light. ¬†

Why do we want to see infrared light?

Lots of stuff in space emits infrared light
column8: so being able to observe it gives us another tool for understanding the universe. For example
column9: sometimes dust obscures the light from objects we want to study ‚Äì but if we can see the heat they are emitting
column10:
we can still ‚Äúsee‚Äù the objects to study them.

It‚Äôs like if you were to stick your arm inside a garbage bag. You might not be able to see your arm with your eyes ‚Äì but if you had an infrared camera
column11:
it could see the heat of your arm right through the cooler plastic bag.

Credit: NASA/IPAC

With a powerful infrared space telescope
column12:
we can see stars and planets forming inside clouds of dust and gas.

We can also see the very first stars and galaxies that formed in the early universe. These objects are so far away that‚Ä¶well
column13: we haven‚Äôt actually been able to see them yet. Also
column14: their light has been shifted from visible light to infrared because the universe is expanding
column15: and as the distances between the galaxies stretch
column16:
the light from them also stretches towards redder wavelengths.¬†

We call this phenomena ¬†‚Äúredshift.‚Äù ¬†This means that for us
column17: these objects can be quite dim at visible wavelengths
column18: but bright at infrared ones. With a powerful enough infrared telescope
column19:
we can see these never-before-seen objects.

We can also study the atmospheres of planets orbiting other stars. Many of the elements and molecules we want to study in planetary atmospheres have characteristic signatures in the infrared.

Because infrared light comes from objects that are warm
column20: in order to detect the super faint heat signals of things that are really
column22: the telescope itself has to be very cold. How cold does the telescope have to be? Webb‚Äôs operating temperature is under 50K (or -370F/-223 C). As a comparison
column23:
water freezes at 273K (or 32 F/0 C).

How do we keep the telescope that cold?¬†

Because there is no atmosphere in space
column24: as long as you can keep something out of the Sun
column25: it will get very cold. So Webb
column27:
doesn‚Äôt need freezers or coolers - instead it has a giant sunshield that keeps it in the shade. (We do have one instrument on Webb that does have a cryocooler because it needs to operate at 7K.)

Also
column28: we have to be careful that no nearby bright things can shine into the telescope ‚Äì Webb is so sensitive to faint infrared light
column29: that bright light could essentially blind it. The sunshield is able to protect the telescope from the light and heat of the Earth and Moon
column30:
as well as the Sun. ¬†

Out at what we call the Second Lagrange point
column31: where the telescope will orbit the Sun in line with the Earth
column32: the sunshield is able to always block the light from bright objects like the Earth
column33:
Sun and Moon.

How do we make sure it all works in space?¬†

By lots of testing on the ground before we launch it. Every piece of the telescope was designed to work at the cold temperatures it will operate at in space and was tested in simulated space conditions. The mirrors were tested at cryogenic temperatures after every phase of their manufacturing process.

The instruments went through multiple cryogenic tests at our Goddard Space Flight Center in Maryland.

Once the telescope (instruments and optics) was assembled
column34: it even underwent a full end-to-end test in our Johnson Space Center‚Äôs giant cryogenic chamber
column35:
to ensure the whole system will work perfectly in space. ¬†

What‚Äôs next for Webb?¬†

It will move to Northrop Grumman where it will be mated to the sunshield
column36: as well as the spacecraft bus
column37: which provides support functions like electrical power
column41:
data handling and propulsion to the spacecraft.

Learn more about the James Webb Space Telescope HERE
column42: or follow the mission on Facebook
column43:
Twitter and Instagram.

Make sure to follow us on Tumblr for your regular dose of space: http://nasa.tumblr.com.

"

Title: Solar System: 10 Things to Know This Week
Content:
Need some space?¬†

Here are 10 perspective-building images for your computer desktop and mobile device wallpaper.¬†

These are all real images, sent very recently by our planetary missions throughout the solar system.¬†

1. Our Sun

Warm up with this view from our Solar Dynamics Observatory showing active regions on the Sun in October 2017.¬†They were observed in a wavelength of extreme ultraviolet light that reveals plasma heated to over a million degrees.¬†

Downloads¬†
Desktop:¬†1280 x 800 | 1600 x 1200 | 1920 x 1200
Mobile:¬†1440 x 2560 | 1080 x 1920 | 750 x 1334

2. Jupiter Up-Close

This series of enhanced-color images shows Jupiter up close and personal
Source_URL: as our Juno spacecraft performed its eighth flyby of the gas giant planet on Sept. 1
column6:
2017.¬†

Downloads
Desktop:¬†1280 x 800 | 1600 x 1200 | 1920 x 1200
Mobile:¬†1440 x 2560¬† | 1080 x 1920¬†| 750 x 1334

3. Saturn‚Äôs and Its Rings

With this mosaic from Oct. 28
column8:
our Cassini spacecraft captured one of its last looks at Saturn and its main rings from a distance.¬†

Downloads
Desktop:¬†1280 x 800 | 1600 x 1200 | 1920 x 1200
Mobile:¬†1440 x 2560¬†| 1080 x 1920¬†| 750 x 1334

4. Gale Crater on Mars

This look from our Curiosity Mars rover includes several geological layers in Gale crater to be examined by the mission
column9: as well as the higher reaches of Mount Sharp beyond. The redder rocks of the foreground are part of the Murray formation. Pale gray rocks in the middle distance of the right half of the image are in the Clay Unit. A band between those terrains is “Vera Rubin Ridge
column10: ” where the rover is working currently. The view combines six images taken with the rover’s Mast Camera (Mastcam) on Jan. 24
column11:
2017.¬†

Downloads
Desktop:¬†1280 x 800 | 1600 x 1200 | 1920 x 1200
Mobile:¬†1440 x 2560¬†| 1080 x 1920¬†| 750 x 1334

5. Sliver of Saturn

Cassini peers toward a sliver of Saturn’s sunlit atmosphere while the icy rings stretch across the foreground as a dark band on March 31
column12:
2017. This view looks toward the unilluminated side of the rings from about 7 degrees below the ring plane.¬†

Downloads
Desktop:¬†1280 x 800 | 1600 x 1200 | 1920 x 1200
Mobile:¬†1440 x 2560¬†| 1080 x 1920¬†| 750 x 1334

6. Dwarf Planet Ceres¬†

This image of the limb of dwarf planet Ceres shows a section of the northern hemisphere
column13: as seen by our Dawn mission. Prominently featured is Occator Crater
column14:
home of Ceres’ intriguing “bright spots.” The latest research suggests that the bright material in this crater is comprised of salts left behind after a briny liquid emerged from below.¬†

Downloads¬†
Desktop:¬†1280 x 800 | 1600 x 1200 | 1920 x 1200
Mobile:¬†1440 x 2560¬†| 1080 x 1920¬†| 750 x 1334

7. Martian Crater

This image from our Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter (MRO) shows a crater in the region with the most impressive known gully activity in Mars’ northern hemisphere. Gullies are active in the winter due to carbon dioxide frost
column15: but northern winters are shorter and warmer than southern winters
column16:
so there is less frost and less gully activity.¬†

Downloads¬†
Desktop:¬†1280 x 800 | 1600 x 1200 | 1920 x 1200
Mobile:¬†1440 x 2560¬†| 1080 x 1920¬†| 750 x 1334

8. Dynamic Storm on Jupiter

A dynamic storm at the southern edge of Jupiter’s northern polar region dominates this Jovian cloudscape
column17:
courtesy of Juno. This storm is a long-lived anticyclonic oval named North North Temperate Little Red Spot 1. Citizen scientists Gerald Eichst√§dt and Se√°n Doran processed this image using data from the JunoCam imager.¬†

Downloads
Desktop:¬†1280 x 800 | 1600 x 1200 | 1920 x 1200
Mobile:¬†1440 x 2560¬†| 1080 x 1920¬†| 750 x 1334

9. Rings Beyond Saturn‚Äôs Sunlit Horizon¬†

This false-color view from the Cassini spacecraft gazes toward the rings beyond Saturn’s sunlit horizon. Along the limb (the planet’s edge) at left can be seen a thin
column18:
detached haze.¬†

Downloads
Desktop:¬†1280 x 800 | 1600 x 1200 | 1920 x 1200
Mobile:¬†1440 x 2560¬†| 1080 x 1920¬†| 750 x 1334¬†

10. Saturn‚Äôs Ocean-Bearing Moon Enceladus

Saturn’s active
column19: ocean-bearing moon Enceladus sinks behind the giant planet in a farewell portrait from Cassini. This view of Enceladus was taken by NASA’s Cassini spacecraft on Sept. 13
column20: 2017. It is among the last images Cassini sent back before its mission came to an end on Sept. 15
column21:
after nearly 20 years in space.¬†

Downloads
Desktop:¬†1280 x 800 | 1600 x 1200 | 1920 x 1200
Mobile:¬†1440 x 2560¬†| 1080 x 1920¬†| 750 x 1334

Applying Wallpaper:
1. Click on the screen resolution you would like to use.
2. Right-click on the image (control-click on a Mac) and select the option ‘Set the Background’ or 'Set as Wallpaper’ (or similar).

Places to look for more of our pictures include solarsystem.nasa.gov/galleries
column22:
images.nasa.gov and www.jpl.nasa.gov/spaceimages.

Make sure to follow us on Tumblr for your regular dose of space: http://nasa.tumblr.com

"

Title: When Dead Stars Collide!
Content:
Gravity has been making waves - literally. ¬†Earlier this month, the Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded for the first direct detection of gravitational waves two years ago. But astronomers just announced another huge advance in the field of gravitational waves - for the first time, we‚Äôve observed light and gravitational waves from the same source.

There was a pair of orbiting neutron stars in a galaxy (called NGC 4993). Neutron stars are the crushed leftover cores of massive stars (stars more than 8 times the mass of our sun) that long ago exploded as supernovas. There are many such pairs of binaries in this galaxy
Source_URL: and in all the galaxies we can see
column6:
but something special was about to happen to this particular pair.

Each time these neutron stars orbited
column7: they would lose a teeny bit of gravitational energy to gravitational waves. Gravitational waves are disturbances in space-time - the very fabric of the universe - that travel at the speed of light. The waves are emitted by any mass that is changing speed or direction
column8: like this pair of orbiting neutron stars. However
column9:
the gravitational waves are very faint unless the neutron stars are very close and orbiting around each other very fast.

As luck would have it
column10: the teeny energy loss caused the two neutron stars to get a teeny bit closer to each other and orbit a teeny bit faster. ¬†After hundreds of millions of years
column11: all those teeny bits added up
column12: and the neutron stars were *very* close. So close that ‚Ä¶ BOOM! ‚Ä¶ they collided. And we witnessed it on Earth on August 17
column13:
2017. ¬†

Credit: National Science Foundation/LIGO/Sonoma State University/A. Simonnet

A couple of very cool things happened in that collision - and we expect they happen in all such neutron star collisions. Just before the neutron stars collided
column14: the gravitational waves were strong enough and at just the right frequency that the National Science Foundation (NSF)‚Äôs Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO) and European Gravitational Observatory‚Äôs Virgo could detect them. Just after the collision
column15:
those waves quickly faded out because there are no longer two things orbiting around each other!

LIGO is a ground-based detector waiting for gravitational waves to pass through its facilities on Earth. When it is active
column16:
it can detect them from almost anywhere in space.

The other thing that happened was what we call a gamma-ray burst. When they get very close
column17: the neutron stars break apart and create a spectacular
column19: explosion. For a couple of seconds
column20: our Fermi Gamma-ray Telescope saw gamma-rays from that explosion. Fermi‚Äôs Gamma-ray Burst Monitor is one of our eyes on the sky
column21:
looking out for such bursts of gamma-rays that scientists want to catch as soon as they‚Äôre happening.

And those gamma-rays came just 1.7 seconds after the gravitational wave signal. The galaxy this occurred in is 130 million light-years away
column22:
so the light and gravitational waves were traveling for 130 million years before we detected them.

After that initial burst of gamma-rays
column23: the debris from the explosion continued to glow
column24: fading as it expanded outward. Our Swift
column27: along with a number of ground-based observers
column28: were poised to look at this afterglow from the explosion in ultraviolet
column30: X-ray and infrared light.¬†Such coordination between satellites is something that we‚Äôve been doing with our international partners for decades
column31:
so we catch events like this one as quickly as possible and in as many wavelengths as possible.

Astronomers have thought that neutron star mergers were the cause of one type of gamma-ray burst - a short gamma-ray burst
column32:
like the one they observed on August 17. It wasn‚Äôt until we could combine the data from our satellites with the information from LIGO/Virgo that we could confirm this directly.

This event begins a new chapter in astronomy. For centuries
column33: light was the only way we could learn about our universe. Now
column34:
we‚Äôve opened up a whole new window into the study of neutron stars and black holes. This means we can see things we could not detect before.

The first LIGO detection was of a pair of merging black holes. Mergers like that may be happening as often as once a month across the universe
column35: but they do not produce much light because there‚Äôs little to nothing left around the black hole to emit light. In that case
column36:
gravitational waves were the only way to detect the merger.

Image Credit: LIGO/Caltech/MIT/Sonoma State (Aurore Simonnet)

The neutron star merger
column38: has plenty of material to emit light. By combining different kinds of light with gravitational waves
column39:
we are learning how matter behaves in the most extreme environments. We are learning more about how the gravitational wave information fits with what we already know from light - and in the process we‚Äôre solving some long-standing mysteries!

Want to know more? Get more information HERE.

Make sure to follow us on Tumblr for your regular dose of space: http://nasa.tumblr.com

"

Title: 13 Reasons to Have an Out-of-This-World Friday (the 13th)
Content:
1. Not all of humanity is bound to the ground

Since 2000
Source_URL: the International Space Station has been continuously occupied by humans. There
column6: crew members live and work while conducting important research that benefits life on Earth and will even help us eventually travel to deep space destinations
column7:
like Mars.

2. We‚Äôre working to develop quieter supersonic aircraft that would allow you to travel from New York to Los Angeles in 2 hours

We are working hard to make flight greener
column8: safer and quieter ‚Äì all while developing aircraft that travel faster
column9: and building an aviation system that operates more efficiently. Seventy years after Chuck Yeager broke the sound barrier in the Bell X-1 aircraft
column10:
we‚Äôre continuing that supersonic X-plane legacy by working to create a quieter supersonic jet with an aim toward passenger flight.

3. The spacecraft
column11:
rockets and systems developed to send astronauts to low-Earth orbit as part of our Commercial Crew Program is also helping us get to Mars

Changes to the human body during long-duration spaceflight are significant challenges to solve ahead of a mission to Mars and back. The space station allows us to perform long duration missions without leaving Earth‚Äôs orbit.

Although they are orbiting Earth
column12: space station astronauts spend months at a time in near-zero gravity
column13: which allows scientists to study several physiological changes and test potential solutions. The more time they spend in space
column14:
the more helpful the station crew members can be to those on Earth assembling the plans to go to Mars.

4. We‚Äôre launching a spacecraft in 2018 that will go ‚Äútouch the Sun‚Äù

In the summer of 2018
column16: a spacecraft that will get closer to the Sun than any other in human history.¬†Parker Solar Probe will fly directly through the Sun‚Äôs atmosphere
column17:
called the corona. Getting better measurements of this region is key to understanding our Sun.¬†

For instance
column18: the Sun releases a constant outflow of solar material
column19: called the solar wind. We think the corona is where this solar wind is accelerated out into the solar system
column20:
and Parker Solar Probe‚Äôs measurements should help us pinpoint how that happens. ¬†

5. You can digitally fly along with spacecraft‚Ä¶that are actually in space‚Ä¶in real-time!

NASA‚Äôs Eyes are immersive
column22: spacecraft locations and trajectories. Through this interactive app
column23: you can experience Earth and our solar system
column24:
the universe and the spacecraft exploring them. Want to watch as our Juno spacecraft makes its next orbit around Juno? You can! Or relive all of the Voyager mission highlights in real-time? You can do that too! Download the free app HERE to start exploring.

6. When you feel far away from home
column25: you can think of the New Horizons spacecraft as it heads toward the Kuiper Belt
column26:
and the Voyager spacecraft are beyond the influence of our sun‚Ä¶billions of miles away

Our New Horizons spacecraft completed its Pluto flyby in July 2015 and has continued on its way toward the Kuiper Belt. The spacecraft continues to send back important data as it travels toward deeper space at more than 32
column28:
and is ~3.2 billion miles from Earth.

In addition to New Horizons
column29: our twin Voyager 1 and 2 spacecraft are exploring where nothing from Earth has flown before. Continuing on their more-than-37-year journey since their 1977 launches
column30: they are each much farther away from Earth and the sun than Pluto. In August 2012
column31: Voyager 1 made the historic entry into interstellar space
column33:
filled with material ejected by the death of nearby stars millions of years ago.

7. There are humans brave enough to not only travel in space
column34:
but venture outside space station to perform important repairs and updates during spacewalks

Just this month (October 2017) we‚Äôve already had two spacewalks on the International Space Station…with another scheduled on Oct. 20.¬†

Spacewalks are important events where crew members repair
column35: maintain and upgrade parts of the International Space Station. These activities can also be referred to as EVAs ‚Äì Extravehicular Activities. Not only do spacewalks require an enormous amount of work to prepare for
column36:
but they are physically demanding on the astronauts. They are working in the vacuum of space in only their spacewalking suit.¬†

8. Smart people are up all night working in control rooms all over NASA to ensure that data keeps flowing from our satellites and spacecraft

Our satellites and spacecraft help scientists study Earth and space. Missions looking toward Earth provide information about clouds
column38: land and ice. They also measure gases in the atmosphere
column39: such as ozone and carbon dioxide and the amount of energy that Earth absorbs and emits. And satellites monitor wildfires
column40:
volcanoes and their smoke.

9. A lot of NASA-developed tech has been transferred for use to the public

Our Technology Transfer Program highlights technologies that were originally designed for our mission needs
column41:
but have since been introduced to the public market. HERE are a few spinoff technologies that you might not know about.

10. We have a spacecraft currently traveling ¬†to an asteroid to collect a sample and bring it back to Earth

OSIRIS-REx is our first-ever mission that will travel to an asteroid and bring a sample of it back to Earth. Currently
column42: the spacecraft is on its way to asteroid Bennu where it will survey and map the object before it ‚Äúhigh-fives‚Äù the asteroid with its robotic arm to collect a sample
column43:
which it will send to Earth.

If everything goes according to plan
column46:
the capsule containing the asteroid sample will make a soft landing in the Utah desert.

11. There are Earth-sized planets outside our solar system that may be habitable

To date
column49: which are planets outside our solar system that orbit a Sun-like star. Of these 3
column51:
some are in the habitable zone ‚Äì where the temperature is just right for liquid water to exist on the surface. ¬†

Recently
column52: our Spitzer Space Telescope revealed the first known system of SEVEN Earth-size planets around a single star. Three of these plants are firmly in the habitable zone
column53: and could have liquid water on the surface
column54:
which is key to life as we know it.

12. Earth looks like art from space

In 1960
column55: the United States put its first Earth-observing environmental satellite into orbit around the planet. Over the decades
column56: these satellites have provided invaluable information
column57:
and the vantage point of space has provided new perspectives on Earth.

The beauty of Earth is clear
column58:
and the artistry ranges from the surreal to the sublime.

13. We‚Äôre building a telescope that will be able to see the first stars ever formed in the universe

Wouldn‚Äôt it be neat to see a period of the universe‚Äôs history that we‚Äôve never seen before? That‚Äôs exactly what the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) will be able to do‚Ä¶plus more!

Specifically
column59:
Webb will see the first objects that formed as the universe cooled down after the Big Bang. We don‚Äôt know exactly when the universe made the first stars and galaxies ‚Äì or how for that matter. That is what we are building Webb to help answer.

Happy Friday the 13th! We hope it‚Äôs out-of-this-world!

Make sure to follow us on Tumblr for your regular dose of space: http://nasa.tumblr.com.

"

Title: Pinpointing the Cause of Earth‚Äôs Recent Record CO2 Spike
Content: A new NASA study provides space-based evidence that Earth‚Äôs tropical regions were the cause of the largest annual increases in atmospheric carbon dioxide concentration seen in at least 2
Source_URL:
000 years.

What was the cause of this?

Scientists suspect that the 2015-2016 El Ni√±o ‚Äì one of the largest on record ‚Äì was responsible. El Ni√±o is a cyclical warming pattern of ocean circulation in the Pacific Ocean that affects weather all over the world. Before OCO-2
column6:
we didn‚Äôt have enough data to understand exactly how El Nino played a part.

Analyzing the first 28 months of data from our Orbiting Carbon Observatory (OCO-2) satellite
column7: researchers conclude that impacts of El Ni√±o-related heat and drought occurring in the tropical regions of South America
column8:
Africa and Indonesia were responsible for the record spike in global carbon dioxide.

These three tropical regions released 2.5 gigatons more carbon into the atmosphere than they did in 2011. This extra carbon dioxide explains the difference in atmospheric carbon dioxide growth rates between 2011 and the peak years of 2015-16.

In 2015 and 2016
column9:
OCO-2 recorded atmospheric carbon dioxide increases that were 50% larger than the average increase seen in recent years preceding these observations.

In eastern and southern tropical South America
column11: severe drought spurred by El Ni√±o made 2015 the driest year in the past 30 years. Temperatures were also higher than normal. These drier and hotter conditions stressed vegetation and reduced photosynthesis
column12:
meaning trees and plants absorbed less carbon from the atmosphere. The effect was to increase the net amount of carbon released into the atmosphere.

In contrast
column13: rainfall in tropical Africa was at normal levels
column14: but ecosystems endured hotter-than-normal temperatures. Dead trees and plants decomposed more
column15:
resulting in more carbon being released into the atmosphere.

Meanwhile
column16: tropical Asia had the second-driest year in the past 30 years. Its increased carbon release
column18:
was mainly due to increased peat and forest fires - ¬†also measured by satellites.

We knew El Ni√±os were one factor in these variations
column19: but until now we didn‚Äôt understand
column20: at the scale of these regions
column21:
what the most important processes were. OCO-2‚Äôs geographic coverage and data density are allowing us to study each region separately.

Why does the amount of carbon dioxide in our atmosphere matter?

The concentration of carbon dioxide in Earth‚Äôs atmosphere is constantly changing. It changes from season to season as plants grow and die
column22: with higher concentrations in the winter and lower amounts in the summer. Annually averaged atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations have generally increased year over year since the 1800s ‚Äì the start of the widespread Industrial Revolution. Before then
column23: Earth‚Äôs atmosphere naturally contained about 595 gigatons of carbon in the form of carbon dioxide. Currently
column24:
that number is 850 gigatons.

Carbon dioxide is a greenhouse gas
column25: which means that it can trap heat. Since greenhouse gas is the principal human-produced driver of climate change
column26:
better understanding how it moves through the Earth system at regional scales and how it changes over time are important aspects to monitor.

Get more information about these data HERE.

Make sure to follow us on Tumblr for your regular dose of space: http://nasa.tumblr.com.

"

Title: 100 Days in Houston
Content:
A lot can happen in 100 days…

At our¬†Johnson Space Center
Source_URL: located in Houston
column6: it has been busy since July 10.¬†Here are six things that have been going on in Houston with our astronauts
column7:
the International Space Station and our next great telescope! Take a look:

1. Our James Webb Space Telescope is Spending 100 Days in a Freezing Cold Chamber

Imagine seeing 13.5 billion light-years back in time
column8: watching the birth of the first stars
column9:
galaxies evolve and solar systems form‚Ä¶our James Webb Space Telescope will do just that once it launches in 2019.

Webb will be the premier observatory of the next decade
column10: studying every phase in the cosmic history of our universe
column11: ranging from the first luminous glows after the Big Bang
column12:
to the formation of solar systems.

On July 10
column13:
the Webb telescope entered Johnson Space Center‚Äôs historic Chamber A for its final cryogenic test that lasts about 100 days behind a closed giant vault-like door.¬†

Why did we put Webb in this freezing cold chamber? To ensure it can withstand the harsh environment it will experience in space.

The telescope has been in a space-like environment in the chamber
column14: tested at cryogenic temperatures. In space
column15: the telescope must operate at extremely cold temperatures so that it can detect infrared light ‚Äì heat radiation – from faint
column16:
distant objects.¬†

To keep the telescope cold while in space
column17: Webb has a sunshield the size of a tennis court
column18:
which blocks sunlight (as well as reflected light from the Earth and Moon). This means that the sun-facing side of the observatory is incredibly hot while the telescope-side remains at sub-freezing temperatures.

2. Our 12 new astronaut candidates reported to Houston to start training

Our newest class of astronaut candidates
column20: reported for training on August 13. These candidates will train for two years on International Space Station systems
column23:
before being flight-ready.¬†

3. Our Mission Control Center operated for 2
column24:
400 hours

While astronauts are in space
column25: Mission Control operates around the clock making sure the crew is safe and the International Space Station is functioning properly. This means workers in Mission Control work in three shifts
column27: 3 p.m. ‚Äì midnight and 11 p.m. ‚Äì 8 a.m. This includes holidays and weekends. Day or night
column28:
Mission Control is up and running.

4. Key Teams at Johnson Space Center Continued Critical Operations During Hurricane Harvey

Although Johnson Space Center closed during Hurricane Harvey
column29: key team members and critical personnel stayed onsite to ensure crucial operations would continue.¬†Mission Control remained in operation throughout this period
column30: as well as all backup systems required to maintain the James Webb Space Telescope
column31: which is at Johnson for testing
column32: were checked prior to the arrival of the storm
column33:
and were ready for use if necessary.

5. Crews on the International Space Station conducted hundreds of science experiments.

Mission Control at Johnson Space Center supported astronauts on board the International Space Station as they worked their typical schedule in the microgravity environment. Crew members work about 10 hours a day conducting science research that benefits life on Earth as well as prepares us for travel deeper into space.¬†

The space station team in Houston supported a rigorous schedule of launches of cargo that included supplies and science materials for the crew living and working in the orbiting laboratory
column34:
launched there by our commercial partners.¬†

6.¬†Two new crews blasted off to space and a record breaking astronaut returned from a stay on space station

Houston is home to the Astronaut Corps
column35: some of whom end up going out-of-this-world. On July 28
column36:
¬†NASA Astronaut Randy Bresnik launched to the International Space Station alongside Italian astronaut Paolo Naspoli and Russian cosmonaut Sergey Ryazanskiy. Joining them at the International Space Station were NASA Astronauts Joe Acaba and Mark Vande Hei who launched September 12 with Russian cosmonaut Alexander Misurkin.

When NASA Astronaut Peggy Whitson landed with crewmates Jack Fischer of NASA and Fyoder Yurchikhin of Roscosmos
column37: she broke the record for the most cumulative time in space by a U.S. astronaut. She landed with over 650 days of cumulative flight time and more than 53 hours of spacewalk time. Upon her return
column38:
the Human Research Program in Houston studies her health and how the human body adapted to her time in space.

Learn more about the¬†Johnson Space Center online
column40:
Twitter¬†or Instagram.

Make sure to follow us on Tumblr for your regular dose of space: http://nasa.tumblr.com.

"

Title: Solar System: Things to Know This Week
Content:
What’s next for NASA? A quick look at some of the big things coming up:

1. We will add to our existing robotic fleet at the Red Planet with the InSight Mars lander set to study the planet’s interior.

This terrestrial planet explorer will address one of the most fundamental issues of planetary and solar system science - understanding the processes that shaped the rocky planets of the inner solar system (including Earth) more than four billion years ago.

2. The Mars 2020 rover will look for signs of past microbial life
Source_URL:
gather samples for potential future return to Earth.

The Mars 2020 mission takes the next step by not only seeking signs of habitable conditions on the Red Planet in the ancient past
column6:
but also searching for signs of past microbial life itself. The Mars 2020 rover introduces a drill that can collect core samples of the most promising rocks and soils and set them aside in a “cache” on the surface of Mars.

3. The James Webb Space Telescope will be the premier observatory of the next decade
column7:
studying the history of our Universe in infrared.

Webb will study every phase in the history of our Universe
column8: ranging from the first luminous glows after the Big Bang
column9: to the formation of solar systems capable of supporting life on planets like Earth
column10:
to the evolution of our own solar system.

4. The Parker Solar Probe will “touch the Sun
column11:
” traveling closer to the surface than any spacecraft before.

This spacecraft
column12: about the size of a small car
column13: will travel directly into the sun’s atmosphere about 4 million miles from our star’s surface.¬†Parker Solar Probe and its four suites of instruments ‚Äì studying magnetic and electric fields
column15:
and the solar wind ‚Äì will be protected from the Sun‚Äôs enormous heat by a 4.5-inch-thick carbon-composite heat shield.

5. Our¬†OSIRIS-REx¬†spacecraft arrives at the near-Earth asteroid Bennu in August 2018
column16:
and will return a sample for study in 2023.

This mission will help scientists investigate how planets formed and how life began
column17:
as well as improve our understanding of asteroids that could impact Earth.

6. Launching in 2018
column18: the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS) will search for planets around 200
column20:
nearby stars.

The Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS) is the next step in the search for planets outside of our solar system (exoplanets)
column21: including those that could support life. The mission will find exoplanets that periodically block part of the light from their host stars
column22:
events called transits.

7. A mission to Jupiter’s ocean-bearing moon Europa is being planned for launch in the 2020s.

The mission will place a spacecraft in orbit around Jupiter in order to perform a detailed investigation of Europa – a world that shows strong evidence for an ocean of liquid water beneath its icy crust and which could host conditions favorable for life.

8. We will launch our first integrated test flight of the Space Launch System rocket and Orion spacecraft
column23:
known as Exploration Mission-1.

The Space Launch System rocket will launch with Orion atop it.¬†During Exploration Mission-1
column24:
Orion will venture thousands of miles beyond the moon during an approximately three week mission.

9. We are looking at what a flexible deep space gateway near the Moon could be.

We‚Äôve issued a draft announcement seeking U.S. industry-led studies for an advanced solar electric propulsion (SEP) vehicle capability. The studies will help define required capabilities and reduce risk for the 50 kilowatt-class SEP needed for the agency‚Äôs near-term exploration goals.

10. Want to know more? Read the full story.

Make sure to follow us on Tumblr for your regular dose of space: http://nasa.tumblr.com.

"

Title: Solar System: Things to Know This Week
Content:
Add to your electronic bookshelf with these free e-books from NASA!

1.¬†The Saturn System Through the Eyes of Cassini

This work features 100 images highlighting Cassini’s 13-year tour at the ringed giant.

2. Earth as Art¬†

Explore our beautiful home world as seen from space.

3. Meatballs and more¬†

Emblems of Exploration showcases the rich history of space and aeronautic logos.

4. Ready for Our Close Up

Hubble Focus: Our Amazing Solar System showcases the wonders of our galactic neighborhood.

5. NASA’s First A¬†

This book dives into the role aeronautics plays in our mission of engineering and exploration.

6. See More¬†

Making the Invisible Visible outlines the rich history of infrared astronomy.

7. Ready for a Deeper Dive?¬†

The NASA Systems Engineering Handbook describes how we get the job done.

8. Spoiler Alert

The space race really heats up in the third volume of famed Russian spacecraft designer Boris Chertok memoirs. Chertok
Source_URL: who worked under the legendary Sergey Korolev
column6: continues his fascinating narrative on the early history of the Soviet space program
column7:
from 1961 to 1967 in¬†Rockets and People III.

9. Take a Walk on the Wild Side

The second volume of Walking to Olympus explores the 21st century evolution of spacewalks.

10. No Library Card Needed¬†

Find your own great read in NASA’s free e-book library.

Make sure to follow us on Tumblr for your regular dose of space: http://nasa.tumblr.com.

"

Title: The National Space Council
Content:
October 5 marks the first meeting of the National Space Council since 1993. But what is it and why does it matter? Let us explain by taking a trip back in history‚Ä¶

We‚Äôve teleported back to 1958‚Ä¶President Dwight Eisenhower is in office and the National Aeronautics and Space Council was created with the signing of the Space Act that year. President Eisenhower chaired the first National Aeronautics and Space Council (NASC). That council continued during the Kennedy, Johnson and Nixon Administrations during which we put an American in outer space with John Glenn in 1962 and put humans on the moon starting in 1969.¬†That Council was disbanded in 1973.

In 1989
Source_URL: President George H.W. Bush‚Äôs Administration reinstated what was known as the National Space Council
column6:
which was designed to help chart national space policy and the roles of multiple federal agencies such as NASA. The Space Council disbanded again in 1993.

On June 30
column8: President Trump signed an executive order reestablishing the National Space Council ‚Äì which brings us to today. The current National Space Council will bring a unified national perspective on space policy to the Administration by coordinating the views of the civilian
column9:
commercial and national security sectors.

So now that you have a bit of the history‚Ä¶why does this matter?

With the Oct. 5 meeting
column10: titled ‚ÄúLeading the Next Frontier: An Event with the National Space Council
column11: ‚Äù Vice President Mike Pence will convene this council and have participation from acting NASA Administrator Robert Lightfoot
column12: as well as a number of Trump Administration cabinet members and senior officials
column13:
and aerospace industry leaders.

During the council‚Äôs first meeting
column14: we will hear from experts who represent various parts of the space industry: Civil Space
column15:
Commercial Space and National Security Space.

You can watch the first meeting of the National Space Council starting at 10 a.m. EDT HERE.

Make sure to follow us on Tumblr for your regular dose of space: http://nasa.tumblr.com.

"

Title: Chasing the Shadow of Neptune‚Äôs Moon Triton
Content:
Our Flying Observatory

Our flying observatory
Source_URL: called SOFIA
column6: carries a 100-inch telescope inside a Boeing 747SP aircraft. Scientists onboard study the life cycle of stars
column7: planets (including the atmosphere of Mars and Jupiter)
column10:
black holes and complex molecules in space.

AND on Oct. 5
column11:
SOFIA is going on a special flight to chase the shadow of Neptune’s moon Triton as it crosses Earth‚Äôs surface!

In case you‚Äôre wondering
column12:
SOFIA stands for:¬†Stratospheric Observatory for Infrared Astronomy.

Triton

Triton is 1
column15: making it the largest of the 13 moons orbiting Neptune. Unlike most large moons in our solar system
column16: Triton orbits in the opposite direction of Neptune
column17: called a retrograde orbit.¬†This backward orbit leads scientists to believe that Triton formed in an area past Neptune
column19:
and was pulled into its orbit around Neptune by gravity.¬†

The Voyager 2 spacecraft flew past Neptune and Triton in 1989 and found that Triton‚Äôs atmosphere is made up of mostly nitrogen…but it has not been studied in nearly 16 years!

Occultations are Eclipse-Like Events

An occultation occurs when an object
column20: like a planet or a moon
column21: passes in front of a star and completely blocks the light from that star. As the object blocks the star‚Äôs light
column22:
it casts a faint shadow on Earth‚Äôs surface.¬†

But unlike an eclipse
column23:
these shadows are not usually visible to the naked eye because the star and object are much smaller and not nearly as bright as our sun. Telescopes with special instruments can actually see these shadows and study the star‚Äôs light as it passes near and around the object ‚Äì if they can be in the right place on Earth to catch the shadow.

Chasing Shadows

Scientists have been making advanced observations of Triton and a background star. They’ve calculated exactly where Triton‚Äôs faint shadow will fall on Earth! Our SOFIA team has designed a flight path that will put SOFIA (the telescope and aircraft) exactly in the center of the shadow at the precise moment that Triton and the star will align.¬†

This is no easy feat because the shadow is moving at more than 53
column24: 000 mph while SOFIA flies at Mach 0.85 (652 mph)
column25: so we only have about two minutes to catch the shadow!! But our SOFIA team has previously harnessed the aircraft‚Äôs mobility to study Pluto from inside the center of its occultation shadow
column26:
and is ready to do it again to study Triton!

What We Learn From Inside the Shadow

From inside the shadow
column27: our team on SOFIA will study the star‚Äôs light as it passes around and through Triton‚Äôs atmosphere. This allows us to learn more about Triton‚Äôs atmosphere
column30:
density and composition!¬†

Our team will use this information to examine if Triton‚Äôs atmosphere has changed since our Voyager 2 spacecraft flew past it in 1989. That‚Äôs a lot of information from a bit of light inside a shadow! Similar observations of Uranus in 1977
column32:
led to the discovery of rings around that planet!

International Ground-Based Support

Ground-based telescopes across the United States and Europe ‚Äì from Scotland to the Canary Islands ‚Äì will also be studying Triton‚Äôs occultation. Even though most of these telescopes will not be in the center of the shadow
column35:
will give us information about how Triton‚Äôs atmosphere varies across its latitudes.¬†

This data from across the Earth and from onboard SOFIA will help researchers understand how Triton‚Äôs atmosphere is distorted at different locations by its high winds and its strong tides!

Make sure to follow us on Tumblr for your regular dose of space: http://nasa.tumblr.com.

"
